metadata.description: Research-backed retail psychology data with citations

sources.title: Eye level is buy level: The importance of in-store product placement
key_findings: Eye-level shelves can boost sales by up to 23%
Products at eye level are seen 9x more than corner placements

sources.title: What Is Retail Shelf Strategy And How To Win (2025)
key_findings: UK coffee manufacturer found shelf 4 (eye level) had 23% greater sales potential
Items on shelf 2 (below eye level) suffered 25% fall in sales
Two-thirds of purchasing decisions made in-store

sources.title: The Psychology of Retail Product Placement
key_findings: Shoppers failed to look at 33-50% of brands on shelf
Center shelf positioning viewed 9x more than corners

sources.title: Strategic Shelf Positioning for Increased Retail Sales
key_findings: High-traffic endcaps can boost sales up to 23%
Products positioned in promotional displays see similar lift

sources.title: 2024 Retail Foot Traffic Recap
key_findings: Overall retail foot traffic increased 0.4% year-over-year in 2024

sources.title: Using retail store traffic patterns to optimize your store layout
key_findings: Analyzing traffic patterns can boost sales by 20-40%
Layout optimization significantly impacts conversion rates

sources.title: BRAND PLACEMENT AND CONSUMER CHOICE: AN IN-STORE EXPERIMENT
key_findings: Shelf position significantly affects consumer choice
Vertical shelf position more important than horizontal

eye_level.description: Optimal visibility zone where shoppers naturally look first

above_eye_level.description: Requires upward gaze; suitable for attention-grabbing products

below_eye_level.description: 25% sales drop compared to eye level; requires downward gaze

bottom_shelf.description: Lowest visibility; typically 35% lower sales than eye level

checkout.description: Highest traffic area with high impulse purchase rate

main_entrance.description: First touchpoint; sets shopping experience tone

center_aisle.description: Baseline traffic for standard aisle locations
